articles.headline: A Financial Mirage in the Desert
articles.snippet: With the benefit of hindsight, there were plenty of signs that Shariah-compliant investments were just as risky as their Western counterparts.
articles.abstract: With the benefit of hindsight, there were plenty of signs that Shariah-compliant investments were just as risky as their Western counterparts.
articles.lead_paragraph: The investments were supposed to be blessed, and the bankers were desperately looking for more people to bless them.

articles.headline: With Tumult at the Top, Washington Times Faces Uncertainty
articles.snippet: In October, the Rev. Sun Myung Moon turned over control of his media company and of the Unification Church to two of his sons, who don’t seem to get along.
articles.abstract: In October, the Rev. Sun Myung Moon turned over control of his media company and of the Unification Church to two of his sons, who don’t seem to get along.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  When John Solomon left The Washington Post last year to become the executive editor of The Washington Times, he was seen as the best hope to push the money-losing paper  owned by News World Communications, a wing of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon’s Unification Church  into the digital age.

articles.headline: In Job Hunt, College Degree Can’t Close Racial Gap
articles.snippet: Race remains a major obstacle for African-American job seekers, even those with degrees from respected colleges.
articles.abstract: Race remains a major obstacle for African-American job seekers, even those with degrees from respected colleges.
articles.lead_paragraph: Johnny R. Williams, 30, would appear to be an unlikely person to have to fret about the impact of race on his job search, with companies like JPMorgan Chase and an M.B.A. from the University of Chicago on his résumé.

articles.headline: In Wake of Dubai, Trying to Predict the Next Crisis
articles.snippet: The travails of Dubai have some economists wondering where other debt bombs might be lurking.
articles.abstract: The travails of Dubai have some economists wondering where other debt bombs might be lurking.
articles.lead_paragraph: Like overstretched American homeowners, governments and companies across the globe are groaning under the weight of debts that, some fear, might never be fully paid back.
articles.byline: By Graham Bowley and Catherine Rampell

articles.headline: Old Clemency May Be Issue for Huckabee
articles.snippet: A busy pardon pen may again lead to political trouble for Mike Huckabee, the former Arkansas governor considered a leading contender for the 2012 G.O.P. nomination.
articles.abstract: A busy pardon pen may again lead to political trouble for Mike Huckabee, the former Arkansas governor considered a leading contender for the 2012 G.O.P. nomination.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Mike Huckabee, a former Southern Baptist minister then serving as governor of Arkansas, granted clemency to Maurice Clemmons nine years ago, he cited his age: Mr. Clemmons was 16 when he began the crime spree for which he was sentenced to more than 100 years in prison.

articles.headline: With Deal, G.E. Clears Path to Sale of NBC
articles.snippet: General Electric reached a tentative agreement to buy Vivendi’s stake in NBC for about $5.8 billion.
articles.abstract: General Electric reached a tentative agreement to buy Vivendi’s stake in NBC for about $5.8 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: General Electric has reached a tentative agreement with the French media conglomerate Vivendi that clears the way for the sale of NBC Universal, including the flagship NBC network, to Comcast, the nation’s largest cable operator, people briefed on the deal said Monday.
articles.byline: By Tim Arango and Bill Carter
